author: Tyler Brooks
title: 8 Massive Thrift Stores In New Hampshire That Offers Outrageously Good Bargains
text:
Looking for amazing thrift stores in New Hampshire where you can find incredible deals?
These 8 massive secondhand shops offer outrageously good bargains and unique treasures!
1. Savers (Manchester)
Walking into Savers in Manchester is like entering a bargain hunter’s paradise.
The sheer size of the place might make your jaw drop.
Row after row of clothing racks stretch across the floor like a sea of potential treasures.
It’s the kind of place where you might come in for one thing and leave with ten.
The clothing section is brilliantly organized by size, type, and sometimes even color.
This thoughtful arrangement saves you from digging through chaotic piles.
Men’s shirts in one area, women’s dresses in another, and kids’ clothes have their own special section.
Everything is neatly tagged and easy to browse through.
The housewares department is where budget decorators strike gold.
Shelves overflow with quirky mugs, practical kitchen gadgets, and statement pieces for your home.
You might find a barely-used blender still in its original box or a set of vintage glasses that perfectly match your style.
Their book section is a reader’s dream come true.
Paperbacks, hardcovers, cookbooks, and coffee table books line the shelves at prices that make buying new seem silly.
What really sets Savers apart is their famous color tag sales.
Each week, certain color tags get marked down even further than their already low prices.
Time your visit right, and you could walk away with a shopping cart full of goodies for under $35.
The store is surprisingly bright and clean, defying the stereotype of dark, musty thrift shops.
Staff members constantly circulate, keeping things tidy and putting out new merchandise.
This means every visit offers a completely different treasure hunting experience.
The shoe section deserves special mention for its impressive selection.
Find barely-worn name brands at a fraction of department store prices.
Their jewelry counter often hides genuine vintage pieces among more modern offerings.
Even the furniture area, though smaller than some sections, regularly features solid wood pieces that would cost hundreds elsewhere.
Where: 93 S Maple St, Manchester, NH 03103
2. Goodwill Store and Buy the Pound Outlet (Hudson)
The Goodwill in Hudson takes thrift shopping to a whole new level of excitement.
Their unique “Buy the Pound” section transforms bargain hunting into a thrilling adventure.
Imagine paying for clothes by weight, just like produce at the grocery store!
Fill a cart with shirts, pants, and jackets, then watch as they’re weighed and priced by the pound.
It’s possibly the most affordable way to shop for clothes anywhere in New Hampshire.
The main store area follows a more traditional thrift store layout but with exceptional organization.
Clothing is neatly arranged by type, size, and sometimes season, making it easy to find exactly what you need.
Their furniture section regularly features solid wood pieces that would cost hundreds or even thousands new.
For just $35, you could walk away with a sturdy end table, a set of dining chairs, or a quality bookshelf.
The electronics section is surprisingly reliable for a thrift store.
Everything gets tested before hitting the sales floor, so that $5 DVD player or $10 stereo system actually works.
Kids’ toys, games, and books are incredibly affordable here.
Many still have their original packaging or all their pieces, making them perfect gifts that won’t break the bank.
The housewares section is a gold mine for kitchen essentials and home decor.
Find complete sets of dishes, cooking utensils, and decorative items at prices that seem almost too good to be true.
What makes this Goodwill location special is how frequently they rotate their stock.
New items appear on the sales floor daily, sometimes hourly during busy donation periods.
This means regular visitors are constantly discovering fresh treasures with each visit.
The staff is knowledgeable and genuinely helpful, not just going through the motions.
They can direct you to specific departments or help you find that perfect item you’re searching for.
For crafters and DIY enthusiasts, the random odds and ends section offers unlimited potential.
Find materials for your next project at a fraction of craft store prices.
Where: 9 Wason Rd, Hudson, NH 03051
3. Wonderland Thrift Shop (Stratham)
Wonderland Thrift Shop truly lives up to its magical name.
This charming store creates a shopping experience that feels more like exploring a carefully curated boutique.
The moment you walk in, you notice the difference from larger chain thrift stores.
There’s a warm, community feeling that makes browsing even more enjoyable.
Their clothing selection stands out for its quality rather than quantity.
Each piece seems hand-selected, with a focus on name brands and items in excellent condition.
You’ll find gently used Gap, Banana Republic, and even higher-end labels at prices that might make you do a double-take.
The housewares section is perfect for anyone setting up their first home or looking to refresh their current one.
Complete sets of dishes, quality cookware, and unique decorative items fill the shelves.
For under $35, you could outfit an entire kitchen with the basics or find that perfect statement piece for your living room.
Seasonal items are one of Wonderland’s special strengths.
They put out holiday decorations well ahead of each season, giving shoppers plenty of time to find perfect pieces.
Halloween costumes, Christmas ornaments, and Easter decorations all make appearances at the appropriate times.
The furniture section, though not huge, offers quality over quantity.
Solid wood pieces, vintage finds, and the occasional modern gem appear regularly.
A coffee table, small bookcase, or accent chair might cost just $25-30, leaving room in your budget for smaller items.
What truly sets Wonderland apart is its status as a non-profit thrift shop.
Your purchases directly support community programs in the Stratham area.
This gives your bargain hunting a purpose beyond just saving money.
The volunteers who staff the store bring knowledge and enthusiasm to their work.
Many have been with the shop for years and take pride in creating a positive shopping experience.
They’re happy to share information about the store’s mission while helping you find exactly what you need.
For crafters and DIY decorators, Wonderland often has fabric remnants, craft supplies, and project materials.
These items are typically priced at just a dollar or two, making creative projects affordable for everyone.
Where: 28 Portsmouth Ave, Stratham, NH 03885
4. Outfitters Thrift Store (Manchester)
Outfitters Thrift Store makes a striking first impression with its historic brick building and bright blue door.
This isn’t your average secondhand shop – it feels more like a carefully curated boutique.
Step inside and you’ll immediately notice the thoughtful organization and clean, bright atmosphere.
The clothing is exceptionally well-arranged by size, season, and style.
No digging through jumbled piles here – everything is displayed in a way that makes shopping efficient and enjoyable.
Their selection of outdoor gear and clothing is particularly impressive and unique among thrift stores.
Find quality hiking boots, ski jackets, camping equipment, and outdoor accessories for a fraction of retail prices.
This makes Outfitters a favorite among New Hampshire’s many outdoor enthusiasts.
The children’s section is a lifesaver for parents watching their budgets.
Kids grow so quickly, and here you can find next-season clothes, often still with tags, at prices that won’t make you wince.
Home decor items are artfully displayed throughout the store, giving shoppers ideas for how to use them.
Vintage kitchenware is one of their specialties, with Pyrex dishes, cast iron pans, and other kitchen classics regularly available.
These items have stood the test of time and often cost less than their flimsy modern counterparts.
The book section, while not the largest, offers a well-curated selection of titles.
Many recent bestsellers make appearances, typically priced at just a few dollars each.
What makes Outfitters truly special is their commitment to supporting families in transition.
Your purchases help fund programs that assist families facing challenges in the Manchester area.
This gives your bargain hunting a meaningful purpose beyond just saving money.
Related: The Massive Antique Shop in New Hampshire Where You Can Lose Yourself for Hours
Related: The Enormous Used Bookstore in New Hampshire that Takes Nearly All Day to Explore
Related: The Massive Flea Market in New Hampshire that’s Too Good to Pass Up
The staff includes both employees and volunteers who are passionate about the store’s mission.
They’re knowledgeable about the merchandise and happy to help you find what you need.
With just $35, you could easily put together several complete outfits or find that perfect statement piece for your home.
The jewelry and accessories section often hides genuine treasures among more common items.
Find vintage brooches, quality leather belts, and stylish scarves at prices that seem almost too good to be true.
Where: 394 Second Street, Manchester, NH 03102
5. Southeast NH Habitat For Humanity ReStore (Newington)
The ReStore is unlike any other thrift shop in New Hampshire.
This unique store focuses primarily on home improvement items rather than clothing or small household goods.
Walking in feels more like entering a discount home improvement warehouse than a typical thrift store.
Imagine finding brand new kitchen cabinets for 70% off retail prices.
That’s the kind of jaw-dropping deal that happens regularly at the ReStore.
The furniture section offers everything from sofas and recliners to complete dining sets at amazing prices.
Many pieces are gently used, and some are even brand new donations from retailers clearing out inventory.
Their lighting section is particularly impressive and popular among bargain hunters.
Find chandeliers, wall sconces, and designer lamps that would cost hundreds elsewhere for under $35.
Building materials like doors, windows, and flooring are major draws for contractors and DIY enthusiasts.
These hard-to-find bargains make home renovation projects much more affordable.
The appliance section often features washers, dryers, refrigerators, and stoves in good working order.
While these larger items might exceed our $35 budget, they’re still incredible deals compared to buying new.
Smaller appliances like microwaves, toasters, and coffee makers usually fall well within our budget.
What makes the ReStore special beyond its unique inventory is its environmental impact.
Shopping here keeps usable materials out of landfills while supporting Habitat for Humanity’s mission.
Every purchase helps fund affordable housing initiatives in the community.
The staff includes knowledgeable volunteers who can answer questions about your home projects.
Many are retired contractors or skilled DIYers themselves, offering valuable advice along with great deals.
The inventory changes constantly, with new donations arriving daily.
This means each visit offers a completely different selection of items.
For crafters and creative repurposers, the ReStore is a goldmine of materials and inspiration.
Find unique cabinet hardware, interesting architectural elements, and raw materials for your next project.
Even if you’re not currently renovating, the ReStore is worth visiting for smaller household items.
Picture frames, mirrors, and decorative pieces often cost just a few dollars each.
Where: 29 Fox Run Road, Newington, NH 03801
6. Corey’s Closet (Hooksett)
Corey’s Closet stands out immediately for its clean, bright interior that feels more like a boutique than a thrift store.
The thoughtful layout and organization make shopping here a genuinely pleasant experience.
Their clothing selection focuses on quality over quantity, a refreshing approach in the thrift world.
You’ll find name brands in excellent condition, often with original tags still attached.
The women’s section is particularly impressive, with everything from casual wear to formal dresses.
Find a designer dress for $15 that would have cost $150 new – the kind of bargain that makes thrift shopping so rewarding.
Men’s clothing isn’t neglected either, with good selections of business attire, casual wear, and accessories.
Quality suits, dress shirts, and ties make this a great stop for professional wardrobe building on a budget.
Their shoe section deserves special mention for its organization and quality control.
Many pairs look barely worn, and you’ll find name brands at a fraction of department store prices.
The children’s department is a lifesaver for parents watching their budgets.
Kids’ clothes are typically priced at just a few dollars per item, and the quality is consistently good.
Accessories like purses, scarves, and jewelry are displayed boutique-style rather than jumbled in bins.
Find a genuine leather handbag for $20 that would cost $200 new, or a silk scarf for just a few dollars.
What truly sets Corey’s Closet apart is their commitment to cleanliness and presentation.
Everything feels fresh and well-cared for, not musty or worn out like some thrift stores.
The staff is friendly and helpful without hovering over you while you shop.
They strike the perfect balance between assistance and allowing you to browse in peace.
With $35, you could easily put together a complete outfit including accessories.
This makes Corey’s Closet perfect for job interviews, special events, or just refreshing your wardrobe.
The store’s layout makes it easy to find what you’re looking for without wasting time.
Sections are clearly marked, and similar items are grouped together logically.
Even the dressing rooms are clean and well-maintained, with good lighting for trying on clothes.
This attention to detail makes the overall shopping experience much more enjoyable.
Where: 1271 Hooksett Rd, Hooksett, NH 03106
7. Marion Gerrish Community Center & Thrift Shop (Derry)
The Marion Gerrish Thrift Shop is housed in a stunning historic building that catches your eye immediately.
With its classic white clapboard exterior and charming tower, it looks more like a historic town hall than a thrift store.
This unique setting creates a shopping experience unlike any other thrift store in New Hampshire.
Inside, the shop has a cozy, small-town feel that makes browsing feel like exploring an interesting neighbor’s attic.
The clothing selection, while not as vast as some larger stores, is carefully sorted and inspected for quality.
You won’t find stained or damaged items here – everything is in great condition and priced to sell.
Their housewares section is perfect for setting up a kitchen or dining room on a budget.
Complete sets of dishes, glassware, and cookware are often available for under $20 total.
The book section is well-organized by genre, making it easy to find your next great read.
Hardcovers are typically just $1-2, while paperbacks are even less – perfect for building a home library.
Seasonal items are a big draw, with holiday decorations appearing well before each season.
This gives shoppers plenty of time to find perfect pieces for upcoming celebrations.
The furniture section, though smaller than some thrift stores, often has quality wooden pieces at amazing prices.
A solid oak end table might cost just $25, leaving room in your $35 budget for smaller items.
What makes Marion Gerrish special is its connection to the community center.
The thrift shop helps support the community center, which hosts local groups and events.
Shopping here directly benefits your neighbors and community programs.
The volunteers are friendly and knowledgeable about the store’s inventory.
Many have been helping there for years and take pride in their little shop.
They can often tell you when new items typically arrive or help you find specific things.
The store has a loyal following of regular shoppers who know that treasures appear and disappear quickly.
This creates a fun, treasure-hunt atmosphere that makes each visit exciting.
For crafters and DIY enthusiasts, there’s often a section of craft supplies and project materials.
Find yarn, fabric, and other creative materials at prices far below retail craft stores.
Where: 39 West Broadway, Derry, NH 03038
8. Salvation Army Thrift Store (Concord)
The Salvation Army store in Concord might look unassuming from the outside.
But step through those doors, and you’ll discover a treasure trove of bargains waiting to be found.
The clothing section is enormous, with options for every family member and every season.
Prices are among the lowest you’ll find anywhere – many items are just $2-4 each.
This makes it possible to completely refresh your wardrobe for under $35.
Their furniture section often has solid, well-built pieces at incredible prices.
A dining room chair might cost $10, while a coffee table could be $25.
The quality varies, but patient shoppers regularly find excellent pieces worth much more.
The housewares department is perfect for stocking a kitchen or dorm room on a tight budget.
Complete sets of dishes, pots and pans, and small appliances are all affordable and practical.
Find everything from basic necessities to unique vintage kitchen tools.
Their book section is extensive, with hardcovers typically priced at just $1.
Children’s books are even less, making it easy to build a home library without breaking the bank.
The toy section is a hit with parents and grandparents looking for affordable gifts.
Many toys are in like-new condition and cost just a fraction of retail prices.
What makes this Salvation Army store special is their color tag sales.
Each week, certain color tags are marked down by 50% or more.
If you time it right, $35 could buy enough clothes to fill an entire closet.
The staff works hard to keep the store organized despite the high volume of donations they receive.
New items appear on the shelves daily, making each visit a new treasure hunting experience.
The store’s mission adds meaning to your bargain hunting.
Proceeds support Salvation Army programs that help people in need throughout the community.
For crafters and DIY decorators, there’s often a section of craft supplies and project materials.
Find yarn, fabric, and other creative materials at prices that make creative projects affordable for everyone.
Electronics, though limited, are tested before being put on the sales floor.
This means that $5 lamp or $10 radio should actually work when you get it home.
Where: 227 Sheep Davis Rd, Concord, NH 03301
Thrift shopping in New Hampshire isn’t just about saving money – it’s about the thrill of discovery!
With just $35 in your pocket, you can transform your wardrobe, decorate your home, or find that perfect unique gift that nobody else will have.
Happy hunting!
